meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>public</kanji> <kanji>task</kanji> is going to be <vocabulary>government business</vocabulary>. You have to think of this public as government to know the meaning of this word easily.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

地 is often used in formal contexts or literature to refer to the <vocabulary>Earth</vocabulary>'s surface, the <vocabulary>ground</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>land</vocabulary> in a more abstract or overarching sense. To say "earth" or "ground" casually, use 地面. For "land," it's 土地.

Take a <kanji>district</kanji> and <kanji>divide</kanji> it and you'll end up with many smaller <vocabulary>division</vocabulary>s and <vocabulary>segment</vocabulary>s. 

区分 is a formal term that refers to dividing or segmenting things into sections or categories based on specific criteria. For example, 区分 might be used when dividing an area into different zones or segments like residential and commercial, or sorting documents into different categories based on their content.

You know that the kanji means <kanji>connection</kanji>. This is a verb, so one meaning is <vocabulary>to be connected</vocabulary>. It can also mean <vocabulary>to be involved</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to be related</vocabulary>. Basically things that have to do with being connected with something else.

Does this all sound familiar? In fact, this is another way to write 関わる, which you already learned! The two have exactly the same meaning, but this version is a bit less common.

You know that 建てる is "to build." This is similar to that, but it's the version where you're not doing the building. Something is just getting built. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to be built</vocabulary>. You can remember that by thinking about how <reading>two</reading> (つ) buildings were built without you noticing. These two buildings just seemed to pop up out of nowhere and, unfortunately, they're now blocking your view.

When a <kanji>light</kanji> shines on how much you've <kanji>prosper</kanji>ed, it's a great <vocabulary>honor</vocabulary>. You don't feel like you did anything so special, but it's really a privilege for the light to come down on you like this.

光栄 is generally used to express a deep sense of gratitude and pride when given an opportunity, receiving a compliment, or being acknowledged in a meaningful way. In those situations it's common to say 光栄です to show you feel honored or privileged.
Something that <kanji>prevent</kanji>s <kanji>water</kanji> is <vocabulary>waterproof</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>watertight</vocabulary>. Time to take a bath with my 防水 cell phone...
Trying to <kanji>prevent</kanji> <kanji>fire</kanji>? Better get into <vocabulary>fire prevention</vocabulary>.

Please <kanji>accept</kanji> this <kanji>territory</kanji>. Oh, you want some <kanji>writing</kanji> to make the deal official? Okay, here's a <vocabulary>receipt</vocabulary>.

This word refers to a document which serves as proof of receiving goods, services, or money in an official setting, like a business transaction. If you’re just talking about the receipt you get while shopping, you can simply say レシート or 領収書.

The <kanji>condition</kanji> <kanji>condition</kanji> is the <vocabulary>condition</vocabulary>. It's also the <vocabulary>circumstances</vocabulary> if you can remember that. It's like saying "What's the condition!??" which is similar to saying "What's the circumstances?"

As you reach the <kanji>limit</kanji> of your <kanji>world</kanji>, you face your <vocabulary>limit</vocabulary> and confront your <vocabulary>limitations</vocabulary>.

This word refers to the maximum extent or limit that something can reach or endure. It conveys the idea of reaching the utmost point beyond which a situation or condition cannot be sustained.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>limit</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to limit</vocabulary>. It is often used in the passive form 限られる, which means <vocabulary>to be limited</vocabulary>, implying that the limiting is being done by someone else.

This is a formal word used to define the limits of time, space, or quantity, or to set restrictions on things. It is also used casually when emphasizing something in particular or considering something to be the best.

The <kanji>period of time</kanji> <kanji>limit</kanji> is the <vocabulary>deadline</vocabulary> for a certain thing. Alternatively, this can describe a <vocabulary>term</vocabulary> for something, like the repayment of debts, or some sort of <vocabulary>due date</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>limit</kanji> is <kanji>nothing</kanji>. What? No limit? That means it will never stop! It is <vocabulary>infinite</vocabulary>!
If 吸収 is "absorption" the verb version is <vocabulary>to absorb</vocabulary>.

Remember how 割る is "to divide"? Now you're learning the intransitive version. Instead of you doing the dividing, something just gets divided or split up. So this is <vocabulary>to be divided</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be split</vocabulary>.

It can also mean <vocabulary>to break</vocabulary>, as in ワイングラスが割れる (the wine glass breaks). After all, when an object breaks, it’s divided into parts, right?
<kanji>Divide</kanji> that price and <kanji>pull</kanji> it apart. You only have to pay for one part! What a <vocabulary>discount</vocabulary>.
You've seen that 準備 is <kanji>preparation</kanji>. This is the verb version, so it means <vocabulary>to prepare</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to get ready for</vocabulary> something.

張る is <kanji>to stretch</kanji>. You're <kanji>stubborn</kanji> and want to stretch out what you're doing right now. Although you're stubborn, you keep doing it. You persevere. That's why this word is <vocabulary>to persevere</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to do one's best</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>pull out</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to pull something out</vocabulary>.

This word often implies that the pulling out requires force or effort. It's a pretty versatile word, and can also cover things like letting the air out of something, draining the water out of something, and even overtaking someone or pulling through difficulties.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>catch</kanji>, so this intransitive verb version is <vocabulary>to be caught</vocabulary>.

This is often a literal, physical catch, but 捕まる can also be used when someone's been gotten ahold of in a figurative way, like when you've finally managed to contact them.
An <kanji>imitation</kanji> <kanji>model</kanji> is obviously not the real thing. It's (usually) a <vocabulary>plastic model</vocabulary> or just a <vocabulary>model</vocabulary> figure or something.

It's a <kanji>prize</kanji> where you are <kanji>give</kanji>n <kanji>gold</kanji>. In business, this is called a <vocabulary>bonus</vocabulary>. You didn't expect it (not your salary) and it is given to you (and is gold, if you're lucky).

Note that you’ll more commonly see its shorter version 賞与.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>include</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to include</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to contain</vocabulary>.

While 含む can be used in everyday conversation, it’s a relatively formal word that is generally used in explanatory sentences.

<kanji>Include</kanji> your <kanji>idea</kanji>s here, but think about the <vocabulary>implication</vocabulary>s they will result in too, especially considering you're just including them now. They have implications!

This word is quite formal, and therefore commonly used in academic or professional contexts.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A "<kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>condition</kanji>" is where nothing is going well. How are things going? Not well. The condition is bad. We're in a <vocabulary>recession</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>transit</kanji>, which is just another word for crossing through or crossing over. That's why this word is <vocabulary>to cross</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to cross over</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>echo</kanji> so the verb is <vocabulary>to echo</vocabulary>.

In the <kanji>shadow</kanji>s you still <kanji>echo</kanji>. Your echo leaves the shadows and hits people, creating an <vocabulary>influence</vocabulary> on them. You're like the shadow person pulling the strings, making things do what you want... influencing them.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It can also be <vocabulary>a vote</vocabulary>, because that's what ballots tend to do.
<kanji>Throw</kanji> a <kanji>ballot</kanji> in the ballot box <vocabulary>to vote</vocabulary>.

When <kanji>light</kanji> shines on a <kanji>scene</kanji>, it's still a <vocabulary>scene</vocabulary>. The light is here to create some drama, also making this a <vocabulary>sight</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>spectacle</vocabulary>.

光景 refers to a scene or sight that leaves an impression, whether it's unfolding in front of you or recalled in your mind. It's often used in a poetic way to describe moments that are especially vivid — whether touching, beautiful, striking, or painful.

Take a look at this <kanji>scene</kanji> and the <kanji>condition</kanji> it’s in. This is the climate of the situation, but more specifically the <vocabulary>business climate</vocabulary>. This word is really only used to talk about the state of business and economic stuff, and tends to appear in technical writing.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>sue</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to sue</vocabulary>.

I've <kanji>announce</kanji>d I'm going to <kanji>sue</kanji> you. To do this, I need to file a <vocabulary>criminal complaint</vocabulary> against you. What's the nature of my complaint? Uh... You suck.

告訴 is a legal term used when someone submits a criminal complaint to the authorities and formally asks them to investigate and prosecute a crime. It's not just any old complaint or accusation — it's an official legal action that carries serious weight.
If you <kanji>sue</kanji> and bring about a <kanji>lawsuit</kanji>, you are bringing about a <vocabulary>lawsuit</vocabulary>.
When you <kanji>apprehend</kanji> and <kanji>catch</kanji> someone, that leads to an <vocabulary>arrest</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>supplement</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to supplement</vocabulary>.

Note that this word is generally considered relatively formal in tone.

The <kanji>candidate</kanji> is <kanji>someone</kanji> who's a <kanji>supplement</kanji> to the entire political system. Despite being a supplement, they're still a <vocabulary>candidate</vocabulary> nonetheless, unless they can win!
The <kanji>energy</kanji> of the <kanji>climate</kanji> is the <vocabulary>climate</vocabulary>. High energy? Climate. Low energy. Climate.

<kanji>Heaven</kanji>'s <kanji>climate</kanji> is <vocabulary>the weather</vocabulary>.

Compared to 天気, this is a more formal term used to describe the weather over the period of one day, multiple days, or even weeks.

The <kanji>time</kanji>'s <kanji>climate</kanji> is the <vocabulary>seasonal climate</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>seasonal weather</vocabulary>.

You’ll almost always see this word used in the context of 時候のあいさつ (seasonal greetings). It's a customary practice to start a letter by discussing something related to the current season before addressing the main topic.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>care</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to care about</vocabulary>.

This word generally implies a more direct physical or verbal expression of care, rather than just mentally caring about someone or something. The exception is when it's used in the negative, like 構わない (I don't mind).

If you <kanji>set up</kanji> something so that it <kanji>become</kanji>s a certain way, that's the <vocabulary>composition</vocabulary> of this thing. That's its <vocabulary>structure</vocabulary>.

構成 refers to the process of assembling several elements to create a cohesive whole or the assembled whole itself. It can be applied to various contexts, such as social structures, family compositions, artistic works, or the configuration of materials.

<kanji>Bind</kanji> and <kanji>set up</kanji> everything so it is <vocabulary>fine</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>fairly</vocabulary>  <vocabulary>sufficient</vocabulary>. 

This word is often used to express that something is adequate or satisfactory, to politely decline an offer or invitation, or to indicate a relatively high degree or extent of something, like:

"No thank you" 結構です
"That's fine, no more" もう結構です
"It's fairly big" 結構大きい
etc.
様 uses its alternative meaning "manner" here, so we have an <kanji>imitation</kanji> <kanji>manner</kanji>. An imitation of the same manner over and over creates a <vocabulary>pattern</vocabulary>.

<kanji>New</kanji> and <kanji>fresh</kanji> is <vocabulary>fresh</vocabulary> (has to be new if you want it to be fresh, after all).

This word is used to describe fresh vegetables, fish, air, and new ideas or experiences, but is not commonly used to describe freshly made food or drinks. This is because the word emphasizes the inherent freshness of the thing being described, rather than its recent production.

Alright, so it's not quite the same, but something that is <kanji>fresh</kanji> is also <vocabulary>vivid</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>splendid</vocabulary>. I know those are a couple things I'd associate with freshness. Try to make the connection here before moving on.

<kanji>Fresh</kanji> <kanji>fish</kanji> is <vocabulary>fresh fish</vocabulary> (and the best fish, nom nom nom).

This is a fairly specialized word that you’d mostly see at a market. To describe fresh fish more generally, you can just say 新鮮な魚.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>effective</kanji>. The verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be effective</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to work effectively</vocabulary> (since "to effective" doesn't make sense).

This word is used to describe something that works effectively and as intended, such as medicine that achieves the desired effect or brakes that effectively stop the car.
The <kanji>fruit</kanji> of something that's <kanji>effective</kanji> is <vocabulary>an effect</vocabulary>.
Your <kanji>effective</kanji> <kanji>percent</kanji> shows how effective you are. If you're at an effective percent of 80%, that's your <vocabulary>efficiency</vocabulary>.

Your <kanji>place</kanji> of <kanji>belong</kanji>ing describes your <vocabulary>affiliation</vocabulary>. It’s where you <vocabulary>belong to</vocabulary>. 

This is often used to describe a person’s affiliation or membership to a particular organization, team, or group.
Even <kanji>gold</kanji> <kanji>belong</kanji>s to a family... the family of <vocabulary>metal</vocabulary>s!
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>accustomed</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to become accustomed</vocabulary>.
I've <kanji>learn</kanji>ed to be <kanji>accustomed</kanji> to this. It has become my <vocabulary>custom</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>habit</vocabulary>.

This is the same as the kanji 豊, making it <vocabulary>plentiful</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>abundant</vocabulary>. It can also mean <vocabulary>rich</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>wealthy</vocabulary>.

豊か is a versatile and nuanced word that conveys a sense of abundance and richness in various aspects of life. It implies a positive and prosperous state, going beyond just material wealth or great quantity, and encompassing overall well-being and fulfillment.

If you're plentiful and full, you could say you're plump or full-figured... in other words, you're not a snack, you're the Whole. Damn. Meal. This is a literary expression used to describe the physical appearance of a woman's body, often focusing on a well-endowed chest.
I am <kanji>full</kanji> and <kanji>sufficient</kanji>. I am <vocabulary>satisfied</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>full</kanji> <kanji>moon</kanji> is a <vocabulary>full moon</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Full</kanji> of <kanji>member</kanji>s, so sorry, no more room. This place is a <vocabulary>full house</vocabulary>. That means there is <vocabulary>no vacancy</vocabulary> here.

<kanji>Full</kanji> <kanji>point</kanji>s are when you get a <vocabulary>perfect score</vocabulary>.

満点 can also be used to describe a state of being at the pinnacle of a certain quality or standard, such as サービス満点 (excellent service) or 栄養満点 (highly nutritious).

Does being <kanji>obese</kanji> mean you're always <kanji>full</kanji>? Of course not. But clearly that's what the people who coined the Japanese word for <vocabulary>obesity</vocabulary> thought... You can see there are some implicit biases in these kanji!
Your <kanji>fee</kanji> for being <kanji>obese</kanji> is lots of <vocabulary>manure</vocabulary> coming out of your butt. If you eat a lot you'll poop a lot of manure.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>scroll</kanji>. But, you don't "to scroll." What do you do to scrolls, though? You roll them up, making this word "<vocabulary>to roll</vocabulary>."

This word can also mean <vocabulary>to wind</vocabulary>, like when winding thread or a watch, or <vocabulary>to wrap</vocabulary> when involving a rolling or coiling motion, like wrapping sushi in seaweed or wrapping a cozy scarf around your neck.
<kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>scroll</kanji> is one scroll back in the day, but now it refers to books and means <vocabulary>one volume</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>scroll</kanji> that's <kanji>below</kanji> is the last scroll you read, making it the <vocabulary>last volume</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>above</kanji> <kanji>scroll</kanji> is the top scroll, the one you read first. It's the <vocabulary>first volume</vocabulary>. Many Japanese books come in parts, so look for this if you want to get the first one.

The number <kanji>two</kanji> <kanji>scroll</kanji> is the <vocabulary>second volume</vocabulary>. With Japanese books, they often come in pieces with groups of three being common. This represents the <vocabulary>second volume</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>search</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to search for</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to seek</vocabulary>.

When you <kanji>search</kanji> and <kanji>inspect</kanji> things, you are probably part of a <vocabulary>criminal investigation</vocabulary>. You may even be subject to a <vocabulary>manhunt</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>strangle</kanji> <kanji>kill</kanji> is <vocabulary>murder by strangling</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>strangling to death</vocabulary>.

This is a pretty formal word that you’d see most in police reports and detective novels.

You've learned that the kanji 絞 means <kanji>strangle</kanji>. 絞る, on the other hand, means <vocabulary>to wring out</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to squeeze</vocabulary> something like a towel, or <vocabulary>to narrow down</vocabulary> ideas.
My <kanji>comrade</kanji> who came <kanji>before</kanji> me is my <vocabulary>senior</vocabulary>, my senpai (せんぱい).
The <kanji>comrade</kanji> who's <kanji>behind</kanji> you is your <vocabulary>junior</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>hide</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to hide something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to conceal something</vocabulary>.

You <kanji>hide</kanji> away but you're <kanji>alive</kanji>. You've lived your life, so now it's time to hide and enjoy your <vocabulary>retirement</vocabulary> by making your <vocabulary>retreat</vocabulary> from working life.

This word refers to life after someone retires, and usually implies being retired from active life and having a quiet, maybe even secluded, lifestyle. It can also imply handing over the reins to your successors. The word is a little old-fashioned, but you'll still see it in modern writing.

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: To Hang Something On A Hook

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>hang</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to hang something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to hang up something</vocabulary> (as in to hang it up by a hook).

You can remember this because you must <reading>care</reading> (ける) about the way you hang something up. Without care, it won't stay hanging for long.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>replace</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to replace</vocabulary>. You know that you're doing the replacing because of the <reading>air</reading> (える). You're replacing the air as quickly as you can because if you don't you wouldn't be able to breathe in this small room.

替える means to replace something with another item of the same kind or equivalent, rather than changing its state. Wondering how it differs from 代える? While 代える stresses that you’re using someone or something “in place of another,” 替える simply indicates the act of swapping one thing for another similar thing.
Remember how 男優 was "actor"? Well, I bet you can extrapolate what this one means because it now has <kanji>woman</kanji> in it. This is an <vocabulary>actress</vocabulary>.
A person who lives in a revolution (革命) <kanji>house</kanji> is <vocabulary>a revolutionary</vocabulary>. They want government change! They want to take down the people in power!

革 is <kanji>leather</kanji> and ジャン is short for ジャンパー (Jumper, like a jacket). So, put those together and you have a <vocabulary>leather jacket</vocabulary>.

This word is getting somewhat outdated. The trendier term now is レザージャケット.
<kanji>Long</kanji> <kanji>Cape</kanji> <kanji>Prefecture</kanji>. This will make more sense when you look at the reading. Hint: It's <vocabulary>Nagasaki Prefecture</vocabulary>.
If 呼ぶ is "to call" then this is something similar. This is when you are called by someone (and you're not doing the calling). This word is <vocabulary>to be called</vocabulary>.

This is the transitive version of 現れる (to appear), so rather than something appearing on its own, you’re making it appear. So this word means <vocabulary>to show</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to reveal</vocabulary>, but it’s usually used in set phrases like 姿を現す (to show up) or 正体を現す (to reveal one's true nature).
The <kanji>scene</kanji>'s <kanji>color</kanji> is the <vocabulary>scenery</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>landscape</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>view</vocabulary>. Looking good, scenery!

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>alive</kanji> and the verb version means <vocabulary>to exist</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be</vocabulary>, for anything that is alive and moving, like people and animals. 

The kanji isn't used too often for this word, so when you're writing just use the kana. But you'll see the kanji used sometimes so it's important to be able to recognize it!

Take your <kanji>name</kanji> and <kanji>stab</kanji> someone with it... using your <vocabulary>business card</vocabulary>. Your business card has your name on it. Also, you "stab" it at people who are willing to take it and read it. Not a real stab, but a metaphorical.
Your <kanji>salary</kanji> <kanji>fee</kanji> are the moneys you get for your <vocabulary>salary</vocabulary>. These are your <vocabulary>wages</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>pay</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>decrease</kanji> in <kanji>salary</kanji> is a <vocabulary>pay cut</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Extinction</kanji> will happen as you go <kanji>versus</kanji> extinction. It will happen <vocabulary>absolutely</vocabulary>. It will happen <vocabulary>without fail</vocabulary>. There's nothing you can do to stop extinction.
When <kanji>hope</kanji> has <kanji>died out</kanji>, you have no more hope, only <vocabulary>despair</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Now</kanji> isn’t good enough for <kanji>renew</kanji>al. It’s already <vocabulary>too late</vocabulary>. The time has passed <vocabulary>now</vocabulary>.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. In modern Japanese, 衣 is more often used to describe the clothes your food is wearing, e.g., the coating on tempura or the breading on deep-fried foods.

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>cool</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>cool</vocabulary>.

涼しい is used to describe a comfortable level of coolness, particularly one that's pleasant and <vocabulary>refreshing</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.  The kanji means <kanji>see</kanji> and <kanji>transit</kanji>, but the vocab isn't quite the same. You are going to transit your eyes over an area to take in what you see. So you're really going <vocabulary>to look out over</vocabulary> everything. This word is usually used when you're looking at landscapes or a really large area.

This is a combination of the words 規則 and 正しい, that you learned already. If you follow the rules in the correct order, everything will stay <vocabulary>regular</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>orderly</vocabulary>.

This word means that something follows a regular pattern or schedule. It’s commonly used to describe disciplined lifestyles, such as with regular sleep, exercise, and healthy eating habits, and implies that the regularity is desirable.

This is a combination of the words 家庭 and 教師. A "teacher" who only teaches when you're with your "family" is known as a <vocabulary>tutor</vocabulary>. They don't teach you at school, they're a <vocabulary>private teacher</vocabulary> that comes to your home to help you learn.
You know that 規則 means "rule" or "regulation." So a <kanji>not</kanji> "rule" or "regulation" is an <vocabulary>irregularity</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. You already learned that 降りる means "to get off." This is when you're helping something else descend down from something, not when you yourself are getting down. So it means <vocabulary>to take down</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to lower</vocabulary>.

An <kanji>anti</kanji> <kanji>echo</kanji> is still an <vocabulary>echo</vocabulary>! It's just going back and forth with a normal echo. Together they get a weird <vocabulary>reverberation</vocabulary> going.

When you <kanji>obtain</kanji> something you need to keep it safe, so you decide <vocabulary>to store</vocabulary> it somewhere. Then you can always go back and look at the thing you managed <vocabulary>to achieve</vocabulary> or  <vocabulary>to score</vocabulary>, and no one can take it from you.

収める means "to store" with an emphasis on placing something in their proper location. This nuance extends to convey a sense of accomplishment, such as "achieving a favorable outcome.”

It's another verb with the kanji 増! This one means <vocabulary>to increase</vocabulary> too! But!

Just like 増える, this is when something is just increasing on its own. You can use this word to talk about an increase in number, quantity, or degree, but it’s more literary and less common than 増える, except when referring to an increase in degree.

If you try to <kanji>calculate</kanji> something, but instead you feel the urge to <kanji>hang</kanji> your teacher, you know you're doing <vocabulary>multiplication</vocabulary>. It's hard, guys. Like really hard. The hardest kind of math of them all. But you can do it! No one needs to get hanged. And don't hang your head in defeat either. Multiply those numbers like a boss! Hang the numbers instead!!

This is the verb version of the kanji <kanji>superior</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>to surpass</vocabulary>. Someone who is superior is always going to surpass and <vocabulary>to excel</vocabulary> beyond others. That's what makes them so superior in the first place!

This is a formal word that is often used in writing or formal speech.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>catch</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to catch</vocabulary>.

Try to remember the mnemonic from the kanji with this one, because this word isn't used for physically catching things, but for ideas or meanings that you are able <vocabulary>to grasp</vocabulary>, metaphorically speaking.

The kanji means <kanji>strangle</kanji> and this vocab is the verb version of that: <vocabulary>to strangle</vocabulary>. It’s usually used in the phrase 首を絞める, which also means “to strangle.” 

There is another word, 絞る which means "to wring out" that looks very similar. You know that this one is "to strangle" because it has める sticking out of it. Imagine that in the <reading>mail</reading> (める) you get a letter that says "I'm going <vocabulary>to strangle</vocabulary> you!" When you get this in the mail, you know it's about strangling.
A <kanji>person</kanji> <kanji>wolf </kanji> is a <vocabulary>werewolf</vocabulary>. This word is less common than 狼男, but it's used more and more thanks to the card game of the same name!

Something that is <kanji>endless</kanji>ly <kanji>big</kanji> isn't just big, but <vocabulary>huge</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>enormous</vocabulary>.

This word is often used in contexts that involve money, but it can also be used for other things like time, energy, and data.
This is the same 岡山 that you learned with 岡山県. So what's Okayama <kanji>castle</kanji>? Yep, <vocabulary>Okayama Castle</vocabulary>!

Add a に to <kanji>every</kanji> and you get <vocabulary>for every</vocabulary>. This means something happens <vocabulary>at intervals of</vocabulary> a certain time frame or milestone, like <vocabulary>once every</vocabulary> year, month, day, etc.!

Note that this is very frequently written in hiragana, but you'll encounter the kanji version as well, especially when it follows a number.

At the <kanji>present time</kanji> you're providing a <kanji>service</kanji>, so you're <vocabulary>actively working</vocabulary>. 現役 means you have a certain role (such as school teacher or a high school student, etc.) and you're still <vocabulary>active</vocabulary> in that role, as opposed to being retired or having graduated.

This word is also often used to describe students who are taking or have passed a university entrance exam while they were still high school students.

When your shoulders get a little こり, it means you've got <vocabulary>shoulder stiffness</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>stiff neck</vocabulary>. 

The こり here is a nominalized version of the verb こる, which means "to become stiff," so maybe that'll help you remember this!

Remember how 直 can also mean "direct?" Well, if someone has an <kanji>element</kanji> of <kanji>direct</kanji>ness to them, they're probably a really <vocabulary>honest</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>upfront</vocabulary> person.

素直 usually describes someone who's sincere, emotionally open, willing to listen, and not stubborn. In some contexts, it can also imply someone is obedient or compliant. For example, a child who always does what they're told without objection might be called 素直.

As the <kanji>years</kanji> get <kanji>distribute</kanji>d, you slowly turn into an <vocabulary>elderly</vocabulary> <vocabulary>senior</vocabulary>, proud of your <vocabulary>old age</vocabulary>.

This word is used to politely describe an elderly person, as in 年配の方 or 年配者.

You learned 様 is a "formal name ender," but it can also mean <kanji>manner</kanji>. When you attach this to another noun with の and add に on the end to make it an adverb, you can describe something that's being done <vocabulary>similarly to</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>in the same way as</vocabulary> something else. In other words, something about it is just <vocabulary>like</vocabulary> that other thing — almost <vocabulary>as if</vocabulary> they were one and the same!
